oai_dc:dc.dc:title: South Guthrie ASA Paper: research paper
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Owens, Anne-Leslie
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This research paper, presented to the American Studies Association Kentucky-Tennessee Chapter, discusses the Vinegar Hill Cemetery, Guildfield Baptist Church, and the Warfield Rosenwald School.

Established in 1868, Guthrie is a town of the New South; when a railroad junction was completed there in 1870, the town became more than a place name and started to grow. Race sharply defined the town's physical environment, with Guthrie, KY as a white settlement, and South Guthrie, TN inhabited by African Americans. This research paper, presented to the American Studies Association Kentucky-Tennessee Chapter, discusses the Vinegar Hill Cemetery, Guildfield Baptist Church, and the Warfield Rosenwald School.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African American Churches -- Tennessee; African American cemeteries; Julius Rosenwald Fund -- Buildings
